body: This is usually a mismatch in the protobuf library you're using.

> This is usually a mismatch in the protobuf library you're using.

Meaning I compiled the .proto file with a version different from the one I'm including?
Meaning you're using version X of the protobuf library to link while the grpc library you're using is expecting version Y.

> Meaning you're using version X of the protobuf library to link while the grpc library you're using is expecting version Y.

I used the version found in the package downloaded with vcpkg, so I thought that one was the one that grpc library was using. Is this a wrong assumption? How can I know which version is grpc library using, if it's not the one found in the package?

The thing is, we don't own nor publish the vcpkg binary package of grpc, and we have no way of knowing which version it actually requires. The fact protobuf C++ has no stable ABI across minor versions is exactly why we're not distributing binary versions of neither protobuf nor grpc, and why we always recommend building from sources. Using a prebuilt library for the C++ version of grpc and protobuf isn't recommended for this reason.

> The thing is, we don't own nor publish the vcpkg binary package of grpc, and we have no way of knowing which version it actually requires. The fact protobuf C++ has no stable ABI across minor versions is exactly why we're not distributing binary versions of neither protobuf nor grpc, and why we always recommend building from sources. Using a prebuilt library for the C++ version of grpc and protobuf isn't recommended for this reason.

Ok, I understand, thank you very much. I'll give another try to build everything from source as soon as I can, even if I have been trying for weeks without success, for a problem or for another. It seems really hard to make grpc work on Windows.

I routinely use the cmakefile to generate visual studio files and run tests there. This is how we run tests per-pull request, and in our CI, and is our recommended way of building. Have you seen our building instructions at https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/BUILDING.md ?

I already did, but I'm trying again to follow that instructions again. During the build, I have some stuff labeled as "not found", and some tests that fail to compile and other that fail. Though, the cmake generation seems to succeed, outputting the file to the .build folder. After that, the `cmake --build . --config Release` seems to perform with success, with 160 warnings and 0 errors.

But, when I then try to make the HelloWorld example from the provided CMakeLists.txt, I get this error:
`CMake Error at C:/extlibs/grpc/.build/gRPCConfig.cmake:8 (include):
  include could not find load file:

    C:/extlibs/grpc/.build/gRPCTargets.cmake
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  CMakeLists.txt:73 (find_package)`

after setting the path of grpc-DIR and protobuf-DIR to their config.cmake files.
If I try, instead, to add the greater_server.cc and the output files of `protoc.exe --cpp_out, protoc.exe --grpc_out` to a solution created from scratch, including zlib.lib, grpc++_unsecure.lib, libprotobuf.lib and cares.lib (these were, as I understood, the required libraries, aren't they?), I still get these 5 unresolved externals (this time, the libraries are the one built from sources from the guide you linked)

1>helloworld.pb.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "public: virtual unsigned char * __thiscall google::protobuf::MessageLite::InternalSerializeWithCachedSizesToArray(unsigned char *)const " (?InternalSerializeWithCachedSizesToArray@MessageLite@protobuf@google@@UBEPAEPAE@Z)

1>helloworld.pb.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol "void __cdecl google::protobuf::internal::AddDescriptors(struct google::protobuf::internal::DescriptorTable *,void (__cdecl*const *)(void),int)" (?AddDescriptors@internal@protobuf@google@@YAXPAUDescriptorTable@123@PBQ6AXXZH@Z) referenced in function "void __cdecl AddDescriptors_helloworld_2eproto(void)" (?AddDescriptors_helloworld_2eproto@@YAXXZ)`
Right, that's fair. Our examples might not be the best thing at the moment.
So, which are the libraries to include to make it work? As I said, I tried to include zlib, cares, grpc++_unsecure and libprotobuf but without success

I was able to solve that unresolved externals, switching my project configuration to Release, I didn't realize I had it set on Debug while I built grpc on Release. Now I have these other errors:

I mean, it seems that when I solve a problem,there's a ton of other ones waiting for me.

See the C++ usage instructions here: 
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/cpp#cmake (for each of the ways of installing there's a link to a cmake buildfile).
For these methods of including gRPC in your project, we also have a continuous tests that verify that it's buildable (and installable) - and those tests are green.
See scripts here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/test/distrib/cpp and compare what you're doing step by step - you might find the reason why things are not working for you.

was found in any module directory.

Any new clue about what I am missing?
